text: we know them almost as well as after our
own children and we love them equally
because an elephant can read your heart
and you're not going to be successful
unless you love that animal I was born
in Kenya in Nakuru
and have lived here all my life I fell
in love with David children and married
David in 1960 he was very well known as
a pioneer women of solve a National Park
I've raised nearly all species of
African wildlife orphans buffaloes
rhinos giraffes but the elephants have
been the greatest challenge poaching was
a problem huge problem it still is a
huge problem
we had orphaned elephants who came in
older age three and four you know that
the dead mothers have died during the
drought or being shot by poachers but we
never managed to keep an infant elephant
alive
David died in 1977 and that's when we
set up the David Sheldrick Wildlife
Trust to try and carry on his work the
big leap was the infant elephants
nobody had managed to do that first two
orphaned elephants we managed to raise
from early infancy was in 1987 first
elephant that came in we didn't even
have a stable it slipped in my daughter
jewels bedroom and it sort of grew from
that
but in infancy they're very very
difficult to raise they're exceedingly
fragile and an elephant is an infant and
milk dependent for the first three years
of life and needs milk up until the age
of five they cannot tolerate the fat in
cow's milk that kills some straightaway
they get diarrhea and you can lose them
overnight they dehydrate very quickly
then I went around trying to find baby
formulas that had many vegetable fat and
that that worked you know with
difficulty it wasn't ideal it's not
Mother's Milk
and over the years we've managed to
raise over 200 through the nursery but
we've probably lost almost that number
as well when they lose their elephant
family there's a lot of stress involved
grief I mean they mourn and grieve the
elephant family just as we do and during
that time you can have a lot of problems
if you have to calm them down you can
only do that with a lot of tender loving
care and with the input of the other
elephants we've got a wonderful team of
keepers people that really care about
elephants and and love what they do they
all make it yeah they have got different
personalities but I love them all now
their best part of it is uh
they never forget those guys who took
care of them when they were young until
they join the world so they do come back
from time to time we always want to
reintegrate it them and return it back
where it belongs and you know if the
animal loves you enough it will come
back to you see that with our X orphans
you know when they have their wild born
babies they bring them back to share
with the keepers that raise them
themselves through childhood the best
gift you can give a wild animal is to
set it free
